query: In a captive breeding program for Australian frogs, what are the most effective interventions to stimulate successful breeding?
relevant_summary: Evidence from reviews and replicated studies reports that hormone treatments can stimulate breeding by inducing sperm release in males and, with mixed outcomes, egg production in females; sperm quantity and viability depend on hormone type, dose, and dosing frequency, and eggs induced by hormones have been raised successfully to tadpoles or froglets in several cases [883]. Providing natural substrates (e.g., varied substrates) and enclosure furniture such as rotting logs and hollow bamboo pipes promoted egg laying; in one Australian study these were combined with temporary enclosure flooding, sex‑ratio manipulation, and playing recorded mating calls when breeding occurred [1874, 1876]. Allowing female mate choice was associated with breeding only after introducing egg‑bearing females, manipulating sex ratios, playing recorded calls, moving frogs to indoor enclosures permitting temporary flooding with organic substrates, and, in another Australian before‑and‑after study, increased clutch size when female choice was provided alongside recorded calls, separating sexes outside the breeding period, and allowing females to gain weight before breeding [1882]. Across captive frog programs, reproductive success depended on temperature or simulating wet and dry seasons; breeding began after adding more calling, perching, and laying sites together with simulated wet/dry seasons, and development was affected by parental care, density, and temperature [835, 1876].

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "captive breeding Australian frogs interventions to stimulate successful breeding", "k": 3, "offset": 0}
{"query_string": "captive breeding Australian frogs interventions to stimulate successful breeding", "k": 3, "offset": 3}
{"query_string":"captive breeding Australian frogs interventions to stimulate successful breeding","k":3,"offset":6}
{"query_string":"captive breeding Australian frogs interventions to stimulate successful breeding","k":3,"offset":9}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "835",
  "action_title": "Captive breeding frogs",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Thirty-three studies investigated the success of breeding frogs in captivity.
Twenty-three of 33 studies, three of which were reviews and 30 replicated studies, across the world found that amphibians produced egg in captivity, in four cases by captive-bred females. Seven found mixed results, with some species of frogs or 17–50% of captive populations  reproducing successfully in captivity, but with other species difficult to maintain or raise to adults. One found that frogs did not breed successfully in captivity and another that all breeding frogs died. Seventeen of the studies found that captive-bred frogs were raised successfully to hatching, tadpoles, froglets or adults in captivity. One found that froglet survival was low and another that three species were not successfully raised to adulthood.
Four replicated studies (including one small study) in,Canada, Fiji, Hong Kong and Italy found that 30–88% of eggs hatched or survival to metamorphosis was 75%, as froglets was 17–51% or to adults was 50–90% in captivity.
One review and four replicated studies (including two small studies) in Germany, Italy and the USA found that reproductive success of frogs in captivity depended on temperature or a simulated wet and dry season, but not on whether frogs were housed in high or low maintenance facilities. Three replicated studies (including one small study) in Germany, Australia and Canada found that egg or tadpole development in captivity was affected by parental care, density or temperature."
}

query: What are the documented effects of modifying captive primate diets to better reflect what they would eat in the wild?
relevant_summary: Replacing milk with fruit juice in gorilla diets decreased regurgitation and reingestion [1329]. Feeding lemurs a fruit-free diet was associated with lower aggression and reduced self-directed behaviour [1329]. Offering fresh produce instead of pellet feed increased time spent feeding and reduced inactivity in rhesus macaques [1335]. Providing stinging nettles as browse led captive gorillas to use the same processing skills observed in wild gorillas [1332]. No studies were found testing seasonal modification of ingredients/nutrient composition to reflect natural variability [1336]. No studies were found testing the provision of nectar (including artificial nectar) to primates [1331].

query: For captive carnivores, how does the effectiveness of hiding or scattering food compare to simply changing its location within the enclosure?
relevant_summary: Evidence for hiding food reports: four replicated, before-and-after studies in the USA, UK and Germany and one before-and-after study of black bear, leopard cats, bush dogs, maned wolves and Malayan sun bears found that hiding food increased exploring and foraging behaviours; one replicated, before-and-after study and one before-and-after study in the USA found decreased stereotypical pacing in leopard cats and a black bear; one before-and-after study in the USA found reduced time spent sleeping during the day in Canadian lynx [1915]. Evidence for scattering food reports: one replicated, before-and-after study in Brazil found scattered feeding increased locomotion in maned wolves; one replicated study in Brazil found maned wolves spent more time in the section of their enclosure with scattered food than in a section with food on a tray [1921]. Evidence for changing the location of food reports: one replicated, before-and-after study in Ireland found that altering the location of food decreased pacing behaviours in cheetahs [1918].

Evidence for scattering food reports: one replicated, before-and-after study in Brazil found scattered feeding increased locomotion in maned wolves; one replicated study in Brazil found maned wolves spent more time in the section of their enclosure with scattered food than in a section with food on a tray [1921]. relevant_summary: No evidence was captured for the effects of presenting food to primates that required the use (or modification) of tools [1319].

query: For captive felids, what are some effective alternatives to presenting food frozen in ice for reducing stereotypic behaviours?
relevant_summary: Evidence from carnivore studies on felids indicates several alternatives associated with reduced stereotypic behaviours: • Providing food on an unpredictable/random temporal schedule reduced stereotypic pacing in tigers and cheetahs (1904). • Hiding food around the enclosure decreased stereotypical pacing in leopard cats (1915). • Changing the location of food around the enclosure decreased pacing in cheetahs (1918). • Using devices that simulate live prey (e.g., lures, pulleys, bungees) decreased pacing and increased walking in cougars, though pacing initially increased in tigers (1927). • Feeding whole carcasses reduced pacing in lions, leopards, snow leopards and cougars, but increased pacing in tigers (1901). • Providing bones, hides or partial carcasses decreased the frequency of stereotypic behaviours in lions and tigers (1902).

query: For improving the diet of captive primates, how does presenting whole foods instead of processed compare to providing fresh produce instead of pellets?
relevant_summary: In macaques, presenting whole foods instead of chopped increased the amount consumed and the time spent feeding [1323]. In rhesus macaques, offering fresh produce instead of pellet feed increased time spent feeding and reduced inactivity [1335].

query: In a European zoo setting, what actions are available to simulate seasonal environmental changes to encourage breeding in captive amphibians?
relevant_summary: Available actions to simulate seasonal environmental changes for captive amphibians include: varying artificial rainfall to create wet/dry seasons, which stimulated breeding and egg deposition in studies in Germany and Austria, though no toadlets survived past 142 days in Germany (1872); varying enclosure lighting (e.g., UV boosts) to mimic seasonal shifts, which in a UK study did not change clutch size and increased fungal load in boosted groups (1865); varying water flow/speed in artificial streams for torrent-breeding species (no studies found assessing effects) (1870); varying enclosure humidity using humidifiers, foggers/misters or artificial rain (no studies found assessing effects) (1863); allowing dormancy during simulated drought periods for species from highly seasonal environments (no studies found assessing effects) (1869); simulating rainfall using sound recordings of rain/thunderstorms (no studies found assessing effects) (1867); providing enclosure furniture that supports calling, perching, and egg laying alongside simulated wet/dry seasons, which coincided with breeding onset in Austria and promoted egg laying in a replicated study (1876); varying food provision to reflect seasonal availability (no studies found assessing effects) (1883); and allowing temperate amphibians to hibernate (no studies found assessing effects) (1868).

query: What are the observed behavioural and physiological outcomes of feeding captive primates a diet that more closely reflects their natural nutritional composition?
relevant_summary: In captive gorillas, replacing milk with fruit juice in diets formulated to better reflect wild foods was associated with decreased regurgitation and reingestion [1329]. In lemurs, a fruit-free diet was associated with lower aggression and reduced self-directed behaviour [1329]. No studies were found that directly tested the effects of seasonally modifying ingredients/nutrient composition to reflect natural variability in primate diets [1336].

query: What are the trade-offs involved when feeding whole carcasses to captive carnivores?
relevant_summary:
- Behaviour: Feeding whole carcasses reduced pacing in lions, leopards, snow leopards and cougars, but increased pacing in tigers [1901].
- Nutrition/health: In cheetahs, whole rabbit led to lower blood protein urea, zinc and vitamin A compared to supplemented beef, while another study found lower levels of inflammatory bowel indicators when fed whole rabbit [1901].
- Digestibility/energy: Ocelots fed whole 1–3 day old chickens had lower digestible energy and fat than a commercial diet, and African wildcats showed lower organic matter digestibility than a ground‑chicken diet [1901].
- Nutrient status: In cheetahs, plasma a‑tocopherol, retinol and taurine concentrations were within recommended ranges when fed either a commercial meat diet or whole chicken carcasses [1900].

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "feeding whole carcasses to captive carnivores trade-offs benefits risks welfare nutrition hygiene enrichment", "k": 3, "offset": 0}
{"query_string":"captive carnivores carcass feeding whole carcass risks disease dental injuries parasite pathogen hygiene", "k": 3, "offset": 3}

{"query":"What are the trade-offs involved when feeding whole carcasses to captive carnivores?","summary":"- Behaviour: Feeding whole carcasses reduced pacing in lions, leopards, snow leopards and cougars, but increased pacing in tigers [1901].
- Nutrition/health: In cheetahs, whole rabbit led to lower blood protein urea, zinc and vitamin A compared to supplemented beef, while another study found lower levels of inflammatory bowel indicators when fed whole rabbit [1901].
- Digestibility/energy: Ocelots fed whole 1–3 day old chickens had lower digestible energy and fat than a commercial diet, and African wildcats showed lower organic matter digestibility than a ground‑chicken diet [1901].
- Nutrient status: In cheetahs, plasma a‑tocopherol, retinol and taurine concentrations were within recommended ranges when fed either a commercial meat diet or whole chicken carcasses [1900].","action_ids":["1901","1900"]}

query: To improve the welfare of captive maned wolves, what are the most effective dietary and food presentation interventions documented?
relevant_summary: In captive maned wolves, a plant-derived protein diet increased digestible energy and dry matter digestibility but decreased mineral retention and plasma taurine levels compared to a (supplemented) animal-based protein diet [1903]. Supplementing an animal-protein diet with taurine increased plasma taurine levels in maned wolves [1908]. Scattering food around the enclosure increased locomotion, and maned wolves spent more time in the section with scattered food than in a section with food on a tray [1921]. Hiding food around the enclosure increased exploring and foraging behaviours in a study that included maned wolves among other carnivores [1915].
